reviews.review_text: I'm going to be completely honest. I don't know a lot about trucks, or about trucker life, or about running a trucking business. But American Truck Simulator still appeals to me. Driving along a highway making a delivery while listening to some music, listening to a podcast or watching a twitch stream/youtube video is very satisfying and relaxing, however its debatable if what is available here is worth the price(I'll argue both points of view)  You're given 2 states, and 2 types of trucks at launch. Thats all you get. Granted, more will be available down the line, at launch its a very small pick. You're going to see the same landmarks several times just by playing about as much as I have(A little over 6 hours at this point). You're also going to be doing a lot of the same thing, especially if you don't get a loan early on and just do Quick Jobs like I've been doing. However, if the gameplay thats given is satisfactory enough, I could forgive it, which is is in my opinion.  However, if you've played a lot of Euro Truck Simulator 2, I would recommend you wait on this. There isn't much of a change at all, its basically a well made expansion pack to ETS 2. If you're looking for more of that gameplay with a new environment, $20 might be a fair enough price, but if you're on the fence, wait. I'm sure it'll be on sale a few months down the line, and I'm sure they'll be more content at that point. But I do think its worth the $20 purchase is worth it if you haven't played Euro Truck Simulator before.  The gameplay is nice and relaxing with some light management gameplay tacked on for good measure. Its absolutely worth $20 for me, but I think most people will want to wait.     Wait For A Sale

I was originally really hype for this game. I played so much of Euro Truck Sim 2, so an American version was really exciting. Everything that was in the European version is here, so if you've played ETS before, you'll have no problem skipping all of the tutorials and jumping straight into the game. They added a couple of new features, like choosing your parking difficulty and weigh stations and the lanscapes look exactly like their real life counterparts. They really did their homework in that regard. However, the game was still extremely disappointing. For one, there were only 2 playable states on launch: California and Nevada. This means completing the game is a lot easier and routes tend to be much shorter. I wouldn't mind too much, if it didn't mean traveling on the same highways over and over again because the longest routs usually take you to the same places. The game also only launched with only two trucks too, which is weird because I thought this was called American TRUCK Simulator. I know the lack of trucks was because of licensing issues and they'll be adding more trucks and states later (I believe they already added another truck in an update), but it was still disappointing to see this go a similar route of Sims 4 (a new installation in a franchise with less content than its predecessors). Don't get me wrong though, I still really enjoy what the game had going for it so far, and I've logged quite a few hours into the game already, however, I can't recommend buying it right now since there's not much in it yet. Wait until they add more content, then I really recommend buying it.

To be clear this isn't a bad game however when compared with Euro Truck sim 2 it’s hard to recommend this game over it. If you’re an American this may be different but the appeal to me is to drive around with my truck following the laws of the road and enjoying myself. I know that many people won’t enjoy this style of game, but then again I don’t enjoy Fifa (other football and sport games are available).   The game looks much better than European truck simulator the cities and even down to small details such as cracks in the road. At the end of a job the parking process is much better as you get to choose how you want to park selecting from what is effectively; hard, medium and don’t park. The increase in fuel stations is good as in euro truck you could only buy fuel in a city if you had a garage upgraded. The coast roads look absolutely incredible (but with faster trucks in euro truck would be more fun there).   I know more trucks and roads are coming but I find myself thinking why don’t I just play euro truck instead? The current engines available are low on power and the GPS likes taking you down extremely small roads. Also The game makes the ‘highways’ have more bends in them than the motorways in Britain and Europe. The police surprise attack you every moment you are speeding and they are very sneaky arriving just after a 30 sign that I happen to miss seeing. When you finally crawl up to speed on a ‘highway’ you are forced to slow down as the road just arrives in a city or town that you have no idea about until you either get fined for speeding or crash into cars waiting for traffic lights!!!   In conclusion although American truck Simulator is a good simulator I still feel like Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a better game. On euro truck I have put in 110+ hours (had none steam version for a while) and I have experienced that game to about the full whereas American truck simulator I only have about 3 hours of which I know isn’t a lot but still it is difficult for me to recommend.   So in it's current state I cannot recommend this game, with more trucks and roads in future this may alter my view.  *Disclaimer* I know more trucks and roads are coming and I know that you can get mods for removing the police and increasing engine sizes but I wanted to play this game properly but despite this I wasn’t levelling up very quickly and I wanted to see what truck options were available so I had to use an XP cheat mod so I could see the options. PROS: - Massive cities compared to Euro Truck; took me about 5-10 minutes to simply get out of Los Angeles. Not complex road systems like GTA, but large areas of city scenery - Police patrols instead of traffic cams. If a police car sees you speeding, you hear sirens and they flash their lights, and you get a ticket. - Finally, since it is North American road rules, we can turn right at a red light and not get penalized for it! - Weight stations add a little immersion, don't know what affect they have on gameplay at this time however - Truck interiors seem much more realistic now, may be just because they are familiar interiors with analog gauges. - New trailer delivery system - you can choose at the gate to a) Auto-park the trailer b) Park the trailer in an easy spot c) Park the trailer in a difficult but percise spot, all with different XP bonuses  CONS: - Very few truck brands, and therefore probably fewer models - Much smaller map than Euro Truck at this time, only includes 3 states (Nevada, California, & Arizona). I'm assuming they plan to expand on that. - UI, main menu, sound effects, and in-game HUD are all direct copies from Euro Truck - no originality. - American trucks with the extended front (rather than the flat, rectangular shaped trucks) are much harder to drive at high speeds, takes longer to get from point A to point B, especially on twisted off-roads. - Very unpopular with multiplayer mod, no more than 100 people on at a time on NA or EU servers, as opposed to 2400 on ETS2.  OTHER POINTS: - Already tons of mods out for the game, including trucks, trailers, graphics, gameplay, and more. - swood american music  My opinion: Gameplay 2.5/5 Level Design: 4/5 Bug-free: 5/5 Total: 3.5/5  American Truck Simulator is to Euro Truck, as Civ: Beyond Earth is to Civ V. Why start on the west coast for the first release? That's about as far as you can get from what real trucking is like in the US. California is a bunch of tree hugging hippies, massive conjestion, liberal regulations that making trucking there a joke. You can't even drive classic trucks in that state because of their insane laws so why choose that to start off in? I guess it's time for my review!   Stability / Polishing / Performance: The game is not crazily polished, but it works well and has no major bugs as far as I was able to tell. It's performance is compared to other games rather underwhelming, but it should work on most systems.   Graphics: The graphics aren't all that great. The texture resolution is good, the overall quality of the textures is also fine. But when it comes to complex lighting effects the game doesn't necessarily match today's industry standards. However it doesn't look 'ugly'.  Gameplay: The game is very detailed when it comes to the controls. The physics aren't so bad given it's not aiming for damage models or any fancy stuff. It shows it's muscles when it comes to simulating a lively AI driven traffic world. Eventhough the AI sometimes acts outrageously stupid, there are few games one could compare this game with, but I'd dare to say the AI here is still the smartest, given that (nearly) no other game tries to accurately simulate normal every-day traffic! (even GTA with a much higher budget has NPCs blowing each other up just by accident - this doen't happen here)  The game also has a little background simulation going on for the player's company, which I'd like to recommend to focus on in later titles, since it shows some potential in my opinion.   Models / Game World: The truck models are very detailed and look nicely, if you don't look too closely at the big headlights you can mount at the bumper and the roof of your truck (those have just a plain texture). The AI cars don't look too shabby either.  The game world itself is a little lack-luster. Eventhough they made great improvements compared to the previous title, it's still partially in medieval-ages of game development with sprite-based distant flora and some simplistic general design. You are a truck driver. Your goal is to build your trucking empire, one job at a time. Beginning the game, you'll be introduced to a simple delivery job that explains the controls and acts as a tutorial. Afterwards, you'll be dumped at your garage, tasking with saving up enough money to buy your own truck by doing work for other companies. Eventually, you'll be able to buy your own truck, and gain access to the Freight Market, which pays more than the Quick Jobs from contractors. However, you'll have to pay for your own expenses: damages, fuel, fines, and more.   The graphical design of American Truck Simulator echoes the games of its past. While it does attempt to stay current with visual effects like lens flares, godrays and more, ultimately the game's graphics won't impress anybody. The truck models are highly-detailed, and leave little to be desired, but the textures throughout the world are often muddy, low resolution, and can be a bit of an eyesore up close. However, once you're out on the open highway, it's easy to find yourself getting lost in the long winding road ahead of you, with only subtle mountains in the background as a backdrop. The sun beats down on the hot tar below your tires, and it shines up in your face, effectively blinding you if you look just the wrong way.    These graphics, however, are a double-edged sword. While the game does by no means look great, this also allows for lower-end hardware to play the game, and play it well to boot. The game is not very demanding, and even lower-end configurations will not struggle to drive the game. On an NVIDIA GTX 970, paired with an Intel i7-5820k, I averaged 110fps throughout my gameplay. This is with everything maxed, and 400% scaling.    The trucks look good, the backdrops hold up well, but the ground textures, building textures, and AI vehicles look lackluster for a game released in 2016. When put alongside another brand new release, like Rise of the Tomb Raider, you can clearly see that SCS Software was not out to achieve the best in graphical capabilities.  American Truck Simulator is, at its heart, a simulation game. As such, it does this very, very well. Bar-none, it is the most realistic driving game available on PC, and likely available, period. That being said, the engine used in this game is the exact same engine in SCS Software's previous installment, Euro Truck Simulator 2.This means that while the simulation in this game is excellent, it's no better than the game before it. Granted, there's little room for improvement in the game, so I see no reason to fix what isn't broken here.    Immediately starting the game, you'll find yourself dropped into a truck. On-screen prompts will walk you through the basics of the interface, and then you'll be on your way. This game has excellent gamepad and wheel support, and they should be a breeze to set up if you prefer it over kb+m. Once you're all set up, it's time to hit the road. You'll immediately notice how much weight you feel in your truck. The steering is heavy, the acceleration is a game of patience, and the laws of the road are ever-present, adding another layer of pressure while you're getting accustomed to your new big rig.    Jobs will require you to take a trailer of contents from one location to the next, and your SatNav will indicate your route. This will be your guardian angel as you trek across the land. Below your SatNav, your miles-to-go is displayed, letting you know how much longer you have left in your drive. You'll need to be particularly mindful of your fuel, and your consciousness. As you drive, these two will drain. If you become too tired, you'll drift in and out of consciousness, and eventually pass out at the wheel, racking up fines as you drive while exhausted. If you run out of fuel, you'll find yourself dead in the water in the middle of the road, with your only option being to pay for a tow truck to the nearest rest stop. The world of American Truck Simulator boasts a plethora of winding roads, hills and dusty back roads to drive across. Each offers a distinct style of gameplay while you head towards your destination.   American Truck Simulator™ is a fun game, hindered by a lack of content. While SCS Software plans to release additional trucks and states, in its current state, the game offers little more than a re-skin of its predecessor set in a not-so-interesting location. Fans of the previous game will definitely find many hours of enjoyment, but newcomers are definitely encouraged to look toward the previous title for their first foray into the truck simulation world. Small UI and gameplay improvements are a welcome addition, but it doesn't change enough to make it feel like a new game. With that said, however, it is priced competitively and fairly, and finds itself costing little more than the Scandinavia DLC for the previous game in the series.

TLDR: If you think you might like it, you probably will. If you don't see the point, don't expect it to surprise you. There are problems, but I expect them to improve with DLC and patching.  I'm not much into hard-sim games, but for some reason this one appealed. I couldn't even explain why.  This game doubles up as a hardcore truck-driving simulator, and a casual time-sink.   If you want to get a steering-wheel controller, manual shifter input and analogue pedals, play the whole game from the driver's camera perspective and grind out your hours as a big-rig stalwart, it's well set up for that. Slowly build your business, earn the right to take high-value cargo for long distance hauls, plan your fuel & rest stops, watch your speed and park your trailer perfectly every time for bonus XP.  But if you just want to use your WASD & mouse, pick up a Quick Job and drive from point-to-point for ten minutes, bashing through the occasional stop-start idiot who clogs up the junction, ditching the trailer at the gate and logging off again... well, that's totally fine too. It's a sim. You can be as serious or casual as you like.  Both are fun, in different ways, and the game does well at supporting both styles of play.  POSITIVE I have one thing to say here, but it's a big one: this game is, on occasion, breathtakingly beatufiul. I have had moments when a sunrise vista has opened up before me, after a gruelling 15hr (well, 15m) night drive through a featureless desert, pushing the speed limit to try and hit my destination before blacking out from exhaustion, and the moment has given me *real feels!* Like, a wistful wanderlust, or a warm familiar feeling. In some small way, I felt what it was like to be a long-haul trucker. This can only be achieved by a number of things coming together. Distinct and recognisable landscapes; above-par atmospheric lighting & graphics, sufficient technical challenge to keep you focussed and slightly stressed for long periods of time, and a solid enough engine to make it all feel immersive. I was genuinely startled when some tumbleweeds blazed across the road in my headlights one night. That's only one positive, but it can't be overstated.  NEGATIVE There are bugs. It's a sim, so there are always limitations on realism, but the AI of police and other road users is occasionally crushingly stupid or arbitrary. There is also a limit on the game's size - two states (at launch) greatly scaled-down only gives you a few hours' driving before you've seen it all. The details are pretty good and I'm sure it'll be improved by DLC in future, but for now it's a big limitation. Sometimes, very rarely, using a Steam Controller, the control scheme will just break, and you'll go careening into a barrier at 55mph for no reason. Such immersion-breaking is criminal for a sim, and I hope Steam and/or the developers get on that ASAP. Today my controller suddenly started providing massive haptic feedback, contrary to my settings, so... yeah. New game, new technology. Fingers crossed. The biggest problem, though, is the strategic side of things. Upgrading your truck (beyond a bigger engine & improved gearbox) is very costly but basically pointless. It's a cosmetic change to something you pretty much never see. But then the only other thing you can spend your hard-earned cash on is growing the business, which... just brings in more money. I don't know what else you could expect from a truck sim, but it seems like a one-dimensional management game has been tacked on the side with little purpose.  Once I realised the larger game offered little more than the (casual) Quick Job mode, the game lost a lot of its appeal. It was a cathartic ride up to that point, though, so I'll probably still dip in occasionally, and I'm happy to recommend it for the money. If the challenge of technical driving appeals to you, this is worth a look.

As for those who have played Euro Truck Simulator 2, you will find this game to be very much similar. Truthfully, the only really noticeable differences would have to be the landscape(s), traffic, trucks, e.t.c. The performance and everything is slightly better, (in my case), and it was excellent to begin with in ETS2. I would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoyed the ETS series, and for anyone thinking of trying out the series for the first time.  As for the newcomers, keep in mind this is not a game designed for freeroaming, constantly popping in and out of any vehicle you want, or for professionally managing a business; it's a truck driving sim. You drive trucks under an employer until you make enough money to buy your own truck. From there on you haul various types of cargo to build your wealth. You then move on to expand your garage(s), buy more trucks, hire drivers, and make money. From a broad standpoint, yes it does simulate business, but that's not the primary goal of the game; it's for driving trucks.  Summary summed up: if you want to drive anything you please any time or manage a business from a professional standpoint, this game is not what you're hunting. If you want to drive a semi, (and make money doing so), haul lots of different things, and design trucks for your employees to drive, this is what you want.

It's a subtle spell that American Truck Simulator casts, yet one whose alchemy can be surprisingly complex. The roads are filled with more traffic than prior games, and it's dictated by convincing AI; fellow road-users are beholden to the same everyday rule-set as you, stopping at traffic lights and observing a speed limit that fluctuates as you cross state-lines and keeping an eye out for patrolling police cars that enforce the laws of the road. Negotiating busy highways offers its own challenge, the mirror-signal-manoeuvre that precedes a lane-change becoming a part of your vocabulary as trusty as Street Fighter's quarter-circle fireballs.  Ticking beneath all this like a diesel thrum are the systems that piece each journey together; the acquisition of XP that sees you level up and opens up more trucks and more parts, the growing income that allows you to buy more garages, to hire more drivers and to take on more jobs. There's a satisfying sense of progression that sits neatly alongside your excursions, which themselves can escalate as you move on: longer journeys see you battling fatigue and looking for rest-stops lest you fall asleep at the wheel.  If that all sounds familiar, well it is. Beyond the shift in location and a handful of very minor tweaks - those patrolling police cars, the ability to haul longer cargo and a slightly fancier GPS unit - this is quite simply Euro Truck Simulator 2 with a new lick of chrome and transposed to America, with the front-end and all the slow crawl of empire building it enables near-identical. In many ways, it's a more limited game, too.  More is on its way, and given how Euro Truck Simulator 2 quickly expanded thanks to SCS Software and the modding community's efforts, it's safe to assume American Truck Simulator will slowly fill out. Right now, though, it's an openly modest game - with a £14.99 price tag to reflect that - rather than a full-blown sequel. What you're currently buying into is the pull of those American roads, and the slightly mysterious promise of where they'll head next; Arizona is next on the menu, and after that there's the hope that SCS Software could head all the way to the midwest and beyond.

I rarely ever write a review on a game but this one definitely merits it. First off I have been looking forward to playing this since the first day I heard it was in development. First i'd like to point out the obvious facts that we all know and seem to be the griping points about the game to which I have no problem with, two trucks ( with different configurations ) and two states with 30 cities total. This was known if you read any of the dev's latest pre release blogs. Is it ETS2 quality yet?, no, but neither was ETS2 until the community embraced it and helped the dev's push it to what it has become, an absolutely AMAZING game. The same can and hopefully will be applied to ATS. Yes the initial release is a little bleak, the stock truck sounds are decent, the entire economy is modeled on the ETS platform ( which works perfectly since any of us that have played ETS are very familiar with ) Another gripe ive seen is that the graphics are sub par to ETS2. Keep in mind they went for a grittier look seeing how we're out in the desert not everything is pretty and polished its more sandblasted and rusty. Now if you can look past the initial lack of features continue to follow me. Originally only the boxed retail version of this game was to get any DLC, which the dev's generously gave ALL of us for free including Arizona when it becomes available. Couple that with the fact that they've tripled their manpower to work on finishing the game while keeping up with updating ETS2 thats a lot of work for a smaller software company to take on. I can only look forward to seeing the amazing direction this game is going to progress in the future seeing how the modding community is already full bore churning out content on release day. Here's how I rate the game  - Same addictive game play as ETS2 - New features such as parking methods and weigh stations - Very large map for only 30 cities - improved AI traffic  - mesmerizing scenery transitions  I honestly have no complaints with the game other than a minor gripe about the fine amounts and the 'rolling radars' and a few bugs that obviously are going to be in a new game but overall I foresee myself enjoying hundreds of hours on this title as it progresses. I've only played it for about a half hour so far, so this review will be limited in scope, but I have put over 70 hours into ETS2 and that has got to count for something. It doesn't? Well, whatever. Here are my initial thoughts on ATS:  - It's cheaper at launch that ETS2 was.   Yes, it's technically a smaller game and it's basically the same engine as we got from ETS2, but it's also more affordable. We weren't really promised anything other than their standard Truck Simulator fare set in America, so I don't see a problem with this.  - The graphics look marginally improved over ETS2.  It's true. Many of the textures in ATS are nicer overall than the ones you will find in ETS2. It's not a huge improvement, but it's something.  - There are a few new gameplay aspects.  Perhaps my favorite new addition is the ability to front park when delivering a load. I was never any good at parking the traditional way in ETS2, so it's quite nice to be given the option to earn a few extra EXP for parking the truck in a less than stellar fashion that gets the job done.  Of course, they also went ahead and increased the cost of speeding tickets and whatnot, so that could change the way some people play the game. Oh, and it seemed as it the truck went through fuel a bit faster, but I couldn't really tell with any degree of certainty in just my first few playthroughs.   - They can, and most likely will add DLC to this game.  For those complaining that you only get two states to drive around in, trust me – we will see more. They added new areas via DLC for ETS2, so we're probably going to see the same approach for ATS as well. Once again, although this means added cost down the line, chances are that you'll be able to get a couple DLC packs and still not reach the full price that ETS2 was listed at when it first came out. It's important to put things into perspective, and the reality is that you'll probably get just as much enjoyment out of this game as you got out of ETS2, if in fact you liked that game. You might have to wait a bit longer to get more content, but at least they didn't charge you full price for half a game like you will see with SOME Triple A titles.   Overall, I have to say this game is a win for me thus far.

I wanted to review this game from a Californian's perspective.   The game is generally on par with ETS2. The parking is harder, but the physics and simulation, along with game play, is about the same. So in that respect its not much different than ETS2. However, since we in America are so excited to get an American version of the game, I really want to comment on that part of it. For me the cool part is to be able to base my garage in my real home town.  First, there are a lot of great landmark and local visuals that make this stand out, even in the smaller cities. I found several local landmarks in my own home town which is fantastic. It's much more 'personalized' than ETS2 was, which is great. You won't be disappointed in this.  However, the big let down for me is the immense mistakes on their map of California's freeway/highway system. It's not that its off a little bit, it's just plain WRONG! It seems that the map developers didn't try very hard to follow any real map, and made up their own freeways and routes. There are so many mistakes it's really sad. Takes a lot of fun out of driving in 'my back yard'.  Another interesting thing is the cities that are included map, and the ones that aren't. It's an odd collection of towns that are included, verses those left out, to be sure. You would expect the major cities to be selected, but it seems the developers have a hard time determining what the major California cities are, not to mention where they are located. Must not have had access to Google Earth or Wikipedia I guess.   Then there is the missing geographic features for the road systems. But I don't want to bore you with flat roads where there should be mountain ranges and passes. Someone told me in a discussion not to expect too much, since it's a 'simulator'. But I wonder what they were trying to 'Simulate', since it wasn't California as I know it (at least not our major cities and road system)? I bring this up because many people are hoping for maps of their own states. I wouldn't get your hopes to high if this is any indication.  But, on the whole, it's a fun game, Is it buggy? Of course. But I'm sure they'll improve on it. Personally, I just hope they fix the map a little better. It was still worth the $20 for me!

TL;DR : ATS is a great game which captures the feeling of the open road, however is quite limited at this moment of time.  Ahh, American Truck Simulator. What a great continuation to the Truck Sim legacy.  American Truck Simulator is a sequel of sorts to Euro Truck Simulator 2 (however more like a very large expansion), and a very similar game in fact. American Truck Simulator is, well, a truck simulator, where you must build your land shipping empire from the ground up. You start with nothing. No money. No truck. You also have a very limited amount of jobs you can do (low value, short distance, non-hazardous, and normal times only). From there you do odd jobs, getting hired by other companies and driving their trucks, and slowly start to build up your cash reserves. Once you get enough money, you can buy your very own truck, where you have to do maintenance, pay for gas, and all the other fantastic things that come with owning a vehicle. From then on jobs pay more, and you can upgrade your truck, and even hire drivers and buy trucks for them, and they start to generate income on their own, taking jobs and delivering. (NOTE: You can take out a bank loan, instead of doing dozens of odd jobs, but the interest on the loan can be quite a weight on your shoulders)  Now, do NOT let the word 'Simulator' put you off. This does not feel like a simulator. People generally think of boring, tedious, and mundane when they read 'Simulator'. This game is rather fun, sometimes tense, and liberating. Another point I must make is, I have no idea how, but they perfectly capture the feeling of driving, and the feeling of the open road.  As for the visuals, many textures up close look outdated and many would likely agree they could use a new graphics engine. However, in general the visuals are very satisfying, save for the occasional close-up of an NPC driver.  And then there is the world, which likely recieves the most criticism out of any aspect in this game. The world as of yet consists of California and Nevada. However this area is quite large, it is possible to have fully explored it within 10hrs, and many fans of ETS2 will likely be dissapointed at this, as that game had 16 different countries. Do not be worried however, as there is another state, Arizona, coming very soon. The devs plan to add all of Canada and the USA, and potential for a map stretching down to the Panama Canal, however it will be 'vote with your wallet'. Land will be sold in expansion packs after Arizona most likely.  One more dissapointing aspect is the number of trucks available for purchase at the moment. A grand total of  TWO TRUCKS . This is not due to dev laziness however, but rather because licensing/negotiation with the actual manufacturers has been quite slow. More trucks are on the way.  All in all, this game is great, and I highly reccomend it. Even if you are upset about the lack of content at this moment, there is always ETS2 to tide you over until then. Buy this game, especially with the very low price $28.99CDN ($25USD?)

The AI will merge directly ahead of you...or directly into the side of your trailer.  Two: The freeways. I am American and have been driving on the Interstate system since I was 15, and have never encountered a T-intersection with a stop sign to get onto the freeway, which is present in several locations in ATS. Making a left turn in these intersections is harrowing, as you must wait what seems like forever for a break in traffic that MIGHT be long enough for your slow-accelerating truck to merge safely - and even then, the AI traffic may just crash into you anyway. It just seems like overpasses and on-ramps should be used in these situations, as they would IRL.  Three: This is not really the fault of the developers, and it's not really a complaint, as I understand the restrictions; but three states is just not enough, though it is a great start! I only hope that future DLC map expansions, which I wouldn't mind paying for, come relatively soon. Some of these DLCs may include paint job packs, wheel tuning packs, truck packs and State add-ons.  SCS Software also recently remodeled the map size to the scale of 1:20, including a new, free Arizona DLC. This offers a much better experience for players and it will take longer to finish the whole map, and ultimately, building up your trucking empire to the 'maximum'.  Anyways, I absolutely do reccommend buying ATS. If you are into driving, realism and greats scenery this is a game for you. Relatively realistic enough to be called a 'Trucking Simulator'. Wide turns, traffic not moving so you can merge, cars/trucks blowing red lights and screwing up your paint job, impossible to park without blind-siding yards...it's all here. Even those pesky weigh stations.  If I could ask for more from this game, it'd be the Logs/Time Clocks, as you only get a generalized clock that tells you when you're due for your next 10hr break. It'd be great if you could get out of the truck and explore as well. Give achievements for most coffee drank in 24 hours, worst wrecks imaginable and things like that.  What it does lack that is sorely needed, however, is finer tuned steering control without the use of a gaming wheel/pedals. Both mouse and gamepad turning are tuned to how fast you are moving, and because of this, some wrecks seem unavoidable, as your wheel doesn't turn fast enough to avoid that ever-so-helpful guard rail coming up your left side when passing another vehicle because the game is tweaked to turn slow enough to keep you from flipping.
